newsitem.title: UZBEKISTAN: Uzbekistan halts 1997 wheat purchases temporarily.
newsitem.headline: Uzbekistan halts 1997 wheat purchases temporarily.

text.p: Uzbekistan has temporarily halted wheat imports, earlier forecast to hit 1.0-1.2 million tonnes in 1997, due to a lack of funds, a senior trade source told Reuters on Thursday.
"The delays in wheat buying have occurred because of temporary absence of the necessary funds to import it into Uzbekistan," the source said.
Uzbekistan previously said a small wheat 1996 harvest of 2.7 million tonnes and increased consumption would mean it would need to import a minimum of 1.0 to 1.2 million tonnes of food wheat in 1997.

"The republic won't be able to get around buying on the world market, but it has missed the favourable price situation where it could have saved $70 to $80 on each tonne of wheat bought," the source said.

He said Uzbekistan had imported 150,000 tonnes of wheat from Germany at $193.5 per tonne as of beginning of May, as well as 100,000 tonnes from Kazakhstan at $207 per tonne. Both deals were through commodity powerhouse Cargill of the United States.
The source said a final decision on wheat imports would be taken once the results of the 1997 harvest campaign, due to be completed in the second half of June, were known.
Previous estimates put annual food wheat demand from Uzbekistan's 23 million population at four million tonnes.

Uzbekistan announced in 1995 that it wanted to achieve self-sufficiency in grain, but its goal of producing 4.5 million tonnes a year proved impossible to fulfil due to harsh climactic conditions, underdeveloped infrastructure and a lack of the right kind of seeds.
Uzbekistan harvested 3.5 million tonnes of grain in 1996, including barley, rice and corn, of which the wheat yield was 2.73 million tonnes.
Uzbekistan imported 1.6 million tonnes of wheat in 1996, of which one million were imported through deals with Cargill and Swiss-based Glencore. --Shamil Baigin, Tashkent Newsroom, +3712 391 958
